scenario:
Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) has a strong financial profile with a AAA bond rating and a manageable net debt of $16 billion against $20 billion in cash. The company produced $14 billion in free cash flow over the first nine months of last year, supporting its $8.8 billion dividend outlay. JNJ has a 62-year record of consecutive annual dividend growth and a current yield of nearly 3.5%. The company invests in research and development and makes strategic acquisitions, enabling it to grow its revenue, earnings, and free cash flow.

ExxonMobil (XOM) is the leader in the oil patch, with a strong balance sheet and a net leverage ratio of 5%. The company produced $11.3 billion in free cash flow after covering capital spending, and returned $9.8 billion to investors via share repurchases and dividends. XOM has a 42-year record of consecutive dividend growth and a current yield of over 3.5%. The company plans to increase its earnings by $20 billion and cash flow by $30 billion by 2030, driven by structural cost savings, high-return capital investments, and contributions from its lower-carbon energy businesses.

Realty Income (O) is a real estate investment trust (REIT) with a globally diversified portfolio of commercial real estate. The company has a stable cash flow from its lease structure and a conservative dividend payout ratio of about 75% of its adjusted funds from operations. Realty Income has a top-notch financial profile and is one of only eight REITs with at least two bond ratings of A3/A- or better. The company has a 30-year record of annual dividend growth and a current yield of nearly 6%.
